bibl.title: Letter from D.J. Withington to Philip Showalter Hench, January 9, 1941

div1.p: Withington mentions the publication of a third series of paintings entitled "Pioneers of American Medicine." Withington suggests a meeting in order to discuss this series. He requests information on Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from D.J. Withington to Philip Showalter Hench, January 9, 1941
div1.opener:
John Wyeth V Brother
Incorporated
Manufacturing Chemists,
Philadelphia
January 9, 1941
1600 Arch Street
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
In the absence of our President, Mr. F.
F. Law, your letter of January 4 has come to my attention.

We regret that the copy of “Beaumont and
St. Martin” arrived in poor condition.

We are sending, under separate cover, a
framed copy of this picture, which we trust you will find
satisfactory.

We regret that you were sent an unframed
copy of “Osler at Old Blockley” as we had a few framed copies,
and would have gladly sent one to you. However, you have
probably framed yours by now.

In connection with the third in the series
“Pioneers of American Medicine” we are extremely interested
in your remarks, and would certainly appreciate having any
information whatsoever on the subject of Major Walter Reed.

Mr. Cornwell has just returned from Cuba
where he did research for the painting, and in discussing
it with him the other day, he pointed out the now well-known
fact that Doctor Carlos Finlay played an important part in
this work. We were in Washington just a week ago, collect-
ing data on Major Reed and in about a month Mr. Cornwell will
be ready to commence painting.

Would it be possible for us to arrange a
meeting with you, perhaps in Rochester, at your convenience,
when Mr. George Kellogg and myself, who are handling this en-
tire series, could discuss the matter with you more in detail.

The original paintings will eventually be
given to medical institutions throughout the country on a per-
manent loan basis, for instance, the painting just completed
“Osler at Old Blockley” will eventually hang in the Osler
Memorial at the Philadelphia General Hospital. It is quite
(continued)
Dr. Philip S. Hench
January 1941
-2-
possible that the painting “Beaumont and St. Martin” will hang
in the library of the School of Medicine of the University of
Michigan at Ann Arbor, Michigan.

May I repeat that we are intensely inter-
ested in any suggestions you may have, and we would like to
arrange an appointment to see you at your earliest convenience.
If you would care to address a line to the writer, naming a
date convenient to you, we will arrange to discuss the matter
further.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, JOHN WYETH & BROTHER, INC.
D. J. Withington
Advertising Manager DJW:dr
